image.altText: Isaac Heeney holds his hand in the air in celebration

props.synopsis: Sydney will play either Geelong or Brisbane in the 2024 AFL grand final after running out a convincing 36-point winner over Port Adelaide in their preliminary final at the SCG.

title.children: Slick Swans book ticket to AFL grand final with impressive win over Port Adelaide

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: FT: Sydney is through to the grand final! Swans beat Port by 36 points
3QT: The Swans lead by 40 and have a foot in the grand final
HT: Swans surge ahead and lead Port by 25 points

image.altText: Police in a Glen Osmond street.

props.synopsis: A man who was engaged in a stand-off with armed officers, after allegedly locking himself in a home in Adelaide's east following a break-in at a separate property, has since been arrested, police have said.

title.children: Glen Osmond siege ends with suspect tasered and arrested, police say

image.altText: Kyle Chalmers

props.synopsis: They call him "King Kyle", but swimming champion Kyle Chalmers is on the lookout for the next generation of athletic royalty on a talent search in his home town.

title.children: Olympic champion Kyle Chalmers returns to Port Lincoln in search of future swimming stars

image.altText: A large cloud of smoke rises from a hillside village

props.synopsis: Israeli warplanes carry out their most intense strikes on southern Lebanon in nearly a year of war, heightening the conflict between Israel and Lebanese militant group Hezbollah.

title.children: Israel unleashes heavy strikes on Lebanon as its allies urge restraint

image.altText: A man with a bulletproof vest stands by a black police truck in front of a hedge fence and a shed.

props.synopsis: Another apparent attempt to assassinate Donald Trump leads to a blame game, some troubling questions and an awful sense of deja vu in the United States.

title.children: The US election race has taken another dark turn amid heightened fears of further political violence

image.altText: A woman sits at a kitchen table with her friends, telling stories.

props.synopsis: For friends and fellow-dyslexics Maralyn and Gaynor, continuing a tradition of oral storytelling in their hometown of Wallaroo in South Australia is proving to be a health and confidence booster for the community.

title.children: Why telling stories by heart is good for the mind and more

image.altText: 2008-01-16T120000Z_1761576427_GM1DXBBLHZAA_RTRMADP_3_BRITAIN-DIANA

props.synopsis: The lawyers representing the women say the case was akin to the crimes of sex offenders Jimmy Savile, Jeffery Epstein and Harvey Weinstein.

title.children: Lawyers of multiple women who accused former Harrods owner Mohamed Al Fayed of rape say he was a 'monster'

image.altText: Mike Burgess wearing a suit.

props.synopsis: Heavily redacted government briefing documents made public reveal ASIO checked all Palestinian visa holders in March, with "no adverse information identified".

title.children: ASIO referred every Palestinian visa holder, testing Coalition's claims of lax screening

image.altText: a positive covid test in someone's hand, with the box behind it

props.synopsis: A new COVID variant is spreading rapidly and could soon become the dominant variant around the globe.

title.children: A new COVID variant called XEC is spreading fast. Here's what we know

image.altText: Mark Scott looks serious as he speaks, in front of a blue "National Press Club" backdrop.

props.synopsis: The head of the University of Sydney has apologised to Jewish students and staff, admitting he "failed them" in his handling of an eight-week pro-Palestinian student encampment.

title.children: 'We have failed them': University of Sydney vice-chancellor apologises to Jewish students

image.altText: A display at the South Australian Museum.

props.synopsis: A proposed restructure of the South Australian Museum which would have seen 27 full-time positions abolished has been "withdrawn", following a state government review.

title.children: Controversial museum 'reimagining' vetoed as SA government promises 'recalibrated' future

image.altText: David Anderson answers questions while facing a senate hearing

props.synopsis: The ABC's managing director David Anderson has announced there will be an independent review into a 2022 story that included an "editing error in the audio" of helmet cam footage captured by commandos.

title.children: ABC announces independent review into story that featured 'editing error' in helmet cam footage of commandos

image.altText: The spire of an old church, visible in the distance, through trees.

props.synopsis: Mazan was once synonymous with the best of the south of France: vineyards on one side, lavender fields to the other. Now it's at the centre of a high-profile rape trial, and prosecutors say some of the men here have a dark secret.

title.children: This tiny French town became the centre of a rape trial, and 'everybody knows at least one man involved'

props.synopsis: New Adelaide 36ers coach Mike Wells made no secret of his feelings during a heated training session ahead of his side's NBL opening round clash with the Sydney Kings, and launched into a mid-court spray in which he told his players to stop "f***ing around".

title.children: NBL coach slams basketballers in expletive-laden 36ers training spray ahead of clash with Kings

image.altText: Josh Lush

props.synopsis: Some South Australian farmers are reporting an 80 per cent loss in yield after frost devastated crops across the state, leaving paddocks "pretty much turning brown".

title.children: Frost crushes farmers' hopes of turning around 'worst ever' season

image.altText: Whyalla Steelworks, generic

props.synopsis: The story of Whyalla has been told and retold, and is often framed as a tale of a town and its steel plant. That is not an inaccurate picture, but nor is it a complete one.

title.children: Australia's 'only' rail manufacturer is a 'strategic' asset, but is steeling itself for bad news

image.altText: Two Chinese flags flutter in the wind at a shipping port.

props.synopsis: With the Chinese economy slowing and authorities cracking down on "gratuitous" spending, Australia's export industries are being exposed and impacted in different ways.

title.children: How a push to end 'gratuitous' spending in China could make Australian exporters nervous

image.altText: A baby receiving a vaccination while being held by his mother

props.synopsis: Health authorities are urging at-risk Tasmanians to get vaccinated against the highly infectious illness, as the state prepares for a 12 to 18-month whooping cough wave.

title.children: Tasmania in early stage of whooping cough epidemic as authorities urge vulnerable to vaccinate

image.altText: A woman stares out the window.

props.synopsis: Wounded, Doris was made to walk in chains for days. She never returned to the country she was taken from. Her story was heard as part of the third day of the Truth-Telling and Hearing Inquiry.

title.children: 'A life-long limp': The story of a child who walked for days in chains with a bullet inside her

image.altText: An image of the proposed The Line ending at the sea

props.synopsis: The massive infrastructure project has been advertised for years with otherworldly concept images, but as influencer vlogs from within the brand-new urban development gain traction on social media, audiences haven't been entirely impressed.

title.children: Influencers are posting content from NEOM, Saudi Arabia's megacity under construction. It's not what people expected

image.altText: A white cylindrical submersible descends through water at an angle.

props.synopsis: Appearing before a US Coast Guard panel, Steven Ross says the experimental submersible experienced a platform issue before the vessel imploded.

title.children: Titan submersible's scientific director says it malfunctioned prior to fatal dive

image.altText: A nuclear cooling plant

props.synopsis: Two reports that suggest nuclear power would push up power bills by hundreds of dollars and leave as much as half of Australia's energy demands unmet are being used by the government to tighten the screws on the Coalition over its nuclear proposal.

title.children: In a void of detail, two reports attempt to spell the challenge for Peter Dutton to go nuclear

image.altText: An INTERFET Australian soldier talking to a boy in East Timor, file photo

props.synopsis: September 20 marks 25 years since Australia deployed peacekeepers to Timor-Leste to quell violence.

title.children: 'Softened me as a human being': Australians reflect on 25 years since peacekeeping operation in Timor-Leste

image.altText: A composite image of the woman and man in seperate images.

props.synopsis: The Australian Federal Police allege Kira Korolev travelled to Russia while on leave with the ADF and instructed her husband to log into her work account to send sensitive material.

title.children: Alleged Russian spy couple do not make court appearance as police seize 12 devices in ongoing investigation

image.altText: A woman stands at the bow of a motorboat in the ocean with an island in the background.

props.synopsis: A two-metre crocodile spotted seven times swimming near two Queensland Whitsunday Islands has been euthanased overnight.

title.children: Rangers kill 'very hungry' 2-metre crocodile near popular tourist island

image.altText: A graphic with mouse traps and logos from major banks and telcos.

props.synopsis: Scammers are destroying people's lives — a crackdown on who will cough up when things go wrong has stakeholders divided, writes Michael Atkin.

title.children: Scammers are destroying people's lives — who should cough up if there are systemic failures?

image.altText: Phillip Best outside court

props.synopsis: The District Court heard Phillip Anthony Best was caught filming the 15-year-old girl on a mobile phone from the rafters of a beach toilet block in Bunbury.

title.children: Plumber who filmed teenage girl in toilet walks away with suspended sentence

image.altText: A composite image of an asteroid on a starry background.

props.synopsis: A small asteroid may become a "mini-moon" of Earth's for a couple of months, according to some astronomers. But what makes something a mini-moon, and why are they so hard to spot?

title.children: An asteroid will soon be temporarily looped into Earth's orbit. But does that make it a 'moon'?

image.altText: four people standing together with slogan tee shirts on saying Manyana Matters

props.synopsis: Federal Environment Minister Tanya Plibersek has approved the development of a South Coast NSW forest after four years of community fighting.

title.children: Community 'bitterly disappointed' as endangered forest to be cleared for housing

image.altText: Centrelink sign.

props.synopsis: Here is a list of payments increasing — and by how much — from September 20.

title.children: Multiple Centrelink payments are increasing today. Here's what you need to know

image.altText: A woman and her son looking out at a beach

props.synopsis: The number of "accidental" homeschooled students is increasing across Australia, and some families are reporting positive outcomes.

title.children: Australia has a growing number of 'accidental' homeschool students, and COVID is only part of the reason

image.altText: A plate of donuts and other sugary items.

props.synopsis: The world sugar price surged by about 15 per cent this week, which was easily the industry's sharpest rally of the year.

title.children: There was a 'staggeringly quick' rise in sugar prices this week. Here's why

image.altText: A composite image showing a sign that says dog beer. Rupert Murdoch and a green bag with a B on it.

props.synopsis: Are you across this week's news headlines? Put yourself to the test.

title.children: Weekly news quiz: Dog beer, a Murdoch battle and a controversial green bag
